bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, May 8, 1946

div1.p: Hench inquires about the claims made by Sternberg that he wanted the Yellow Fever Commission to conduct research on the mosquito theory and use human experimentation. Hench thinks that Reed was annoyed with these claims.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, May 8, 1946
div1.opener:
MAYO CLINIC
ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA
DR. PHILIP S. HENCH
DR. CHARLES H. SLOCUMB
May 8, 1946
General J. R. Kean
2804 N Street, N. W.
Georgetown,
Washington, D. C.
My dear General Kean:
div1.p:
I have been so busy--too busy to finish properly this list of questions
as I had hoped to do. In the first place let me apologize for the rather impolite
way the questionairre is phrased. Where I say “Kean this” and “Reed that” etc,
I dashed off a pencilled copy at home and had a substitute secretary write it out.
I meant to have her polish it up, but it got written out just as I had written it.

I am particularly anxious to discuss with you your confidential opinion as to
the claims made by General Sternberg (in his wife's biography are several letters
of his) that he (Sternberg) rather precisely outlined to Reed the program of
research to be followed, specifically on the mosquito theory, the need for human
experiments, etc. Please see Howard's comments on Reed's annoyed reactions on this
score.

I believe you have a copy of the Sternberg biography, and I refer particularly
to the comments which are enclosed with this letter.

I will be in Washington (without my wife, alas) from about Sunday noon,
June 2 to Friday morning, June 7, but will of course have to spend much of my
time at the Surgeon General's office.

Do you think you and Mrs. Franck and I could have a preliminary session
Sunday afternoon, June 2, or would you prefer a later evening session or two?

Fortunately, I already have reservations at The Statler, and hence you must
not worry about that matter. It will be so nice to see you again. I hope to call
on Mrs. Stark at the Shoreham. I've never caught up with her. Last time I was
in Washington, she wasn't well enough to receive me. I do hope I can see her
this time.

Do you know Mrs. Gorgas' New York address? I would like very much to call
on her when I am there on and off between May 23 and June 12.
div1.closer:
Always sincerely, Philip S Hench P. S. Hench, M. D.
